turn.text: Well, I -- that's my understanding of the petitioner's test because that would be an assignment onto the ship in the course of his employment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Wouldn't the union send him onto that?

turn.speaker: william_c_bryson
turn.label: Mr. William C. Bryson
turn.text: Well, that's a possibility and that may be how this will all be resolved.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We're all concern with the brief --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Vickery.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: May it please the Court.
There are two things that I particularly need to say to the court.
Please look at the last two sentences of the legislative history.
They absolutely and categorically confirmed this Court's --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Who doesn't agree?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Footnote 36 on page 13?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Alright.
They absolutely confirmed --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that correct?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: -- this Court's definition of maritime employment as being used in connection with the 1972 amendments.
They state categorically that an employer who does not have any employees who works on navigable waters is not engaged in maritime employment.
There are many companies around the country that do nothing but warehouse work and they don't have a single employee whoever goes on the navigable waters of the United States.
They do exactly the same type of work that the Ford was doing, exactly the same type of work that Bryant was doing but they have not a single employee who does any work on navigable waters.
Congress states categorically that they are not covered employers under those circumstances.
If those people working on the dock who have no other employees employed by their employer cannot be involved in maritime employment either.
This is the bootstrap operation that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The dock is one --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The dock is --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Yes, this Court has held many times the dock is an extension of the land --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppose you --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: -- and has nothing to do

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But it -- that's the type (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Sorry?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's the type you're talking about.
It gives you the same dock.
I wonder what type these docks would cover.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Well, because of the -- because it's well settled in the law that a dock is the extension of the land whether there is water underneath the dock or a land underneath the dock Mr. Justice Marshall, I don't think it makes any difference.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I just wanted to know.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: I see.
I believe that in Ford's case, there was no water under the area --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: -- involved in Bryant's case, most of the piers and warehouses in Galveston are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Didn't you understand?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Oh, the water, I'm sorry, I misunderstood you.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: I misunderstood your question.

Now, the second thing that I need to say to the court and I respectfully request that you carefully consider is whether as federal respondent contends Congress intended to move the Jensen line up to the edge of the terminal or whether Congress simply intended to provide a uniform compensation system for those workers who prior to the 1972 amendments had to cross the Jensen line and that's all Congress did.

It says, the intent is to provide a uniform system to apply to employees who otherwise be covered by this Act for part of their activity that Jensen line is what split their workman's compensation remedy.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, Mr. Vickery, looking at the definition of the term employee in Section 2 (3), it says as you indicate that it means first of all that any person engaged in maritime employment including and then it says including a ship repairman, a shipbuilder and a shipbreaker.
Is it your contention that for ship repairmen or shipbuilder or shipbreaker to be covered by this Act, he must be subject on the day of his injury or death to assignment on work on navigable waters?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: I believe that same maritime employment --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That can be answered yes or no, my question.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I think the same maritime employment requirement exists there.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So if he is a shipbuilder, full time, life long career, a shipbuilder but he's a shipbuilder -- on building a ship before it whatever is on navigable waters, then he's not covered at all and never was and never can be by this Act, is that it?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe that's what Congress says.
I believe that's what they say.
I believe the only possibility of their being a variation in this and I've had no shipbuilder in cases and I'm sorry, I'm uninformed on it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, no, what the statute does express --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: But the Secretary of Labor had defined all of these terms that are used in the Act in connection with the Safety and Health Regulations for longshoring and ship repairers, shipbreakers and shipbuilders.

Those were published in 1960 and the Secretary of Labor's definition of longshoring operations in connection with the Safety and Health Program which he has operated since 1960 is so different from the proposed longshoring operations test that the federal respondents submits to this Court, that is ludicrous.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, my -- my question doesn't have anything to do with longshoring operations.
There's a different part of the definition --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Right.
I understand.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- of an employee.
It means any person engaged in maritime employment including a shipbuilder.
Now, that's -- there's no claim that he is a longshoreman or anything like it.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But let's assume that he is and always has been during his occupation in life, a shipbuilder but that his work is in building ships before they are ever on navigable waters.
Your -- your argument has to be that he's not covered at all by this statute?

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: And that is correct.
That is not maritime employment within the meaning --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: -- within the meaning of the Act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And you do concede that there are shipbuilders all of whose occupational time is spent not on navigable waters.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: I believe the estimate given in the Senate hearings at about 65 to 70% of the work on a shipyard was on navigable waters.
Then those workers who were involved --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And there's 30 to 35% that's not.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: That there would be about 35 that would be not.
So a shipbuilder who builds it entirely on land, who builds a vessel --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And if he is subject on the day of his injury or death to assignment to navigable waters --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- in his occupation --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: He is not engaged in --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- he is not covered by this --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: He is not engaged in maritime employment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: There are shipbuilders --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought that he was.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Your Honor, there are shipbuilders who build tugs, barges and things like that entirely on land taken by trailer --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You mean --

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: -- and then launch them.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: And in my opinion those people are not engaged in --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Some of them in World War II, I remember in Iowa as I remember it.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Consider --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Steamships too.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: e_d_vickery
turn.label: Mr. E. D. Vickery
turn.text: Yes, they can be built entirely on land.
Thank you very much Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
